channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Carney Rules Out Tax Increases to Finance Higher Canada Defense Spending
item.description: Canada’s decision to ramp up military spending at a faster-than-expected pace marks a “significant event” for the country’s fiscal direction, Prime Minister Mark Carney said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Irish Manufacturing Contracts Sharply as U.S. Import Boost Fades
item.description: April factory production was 13.7% lower than in March, a new sign that the eurozone economy was slowing after a strong start to the year as U.S. businesses stockpiled goods.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Taiwan Exports Growth Nears 15-Year High Amid Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Despite the strong performance so far this year, Taiwan’s statistics bureau expects exports to contract in the second half.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: A U.S.-China trade truce wasn’t enough to stem a sharp drop in shipments from China to America last month
item.description: A U.S.-China trade truce wasn’t enough to stem a sharp drop in shipments from China to America last month.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Japan’s Economy Remains at Risk of Technical Recession, Data Shows
item.description: The Japanese economy shrank less than initially estimated in the first quarter but remains at risk of technical recession, which could delay the Bank of Japan’s timeline for raising interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: A debate over the effects of tax cuts is at the core of this summer’s fiscal fight in Congress
item.description: A debate over the legislation’s effects on economic growth and deficits is at the core of this summer’s fiscal fight in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Richard Rubin

item.title: Export controls—a major concern for industries worldwide—are moving to the top of the agenda of Monday trade talks between the U.S. and China
item.description: The trade war’s focus has shifted from tariffs to countries’ curbs on critical products and materials.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Dolls have become an unlikely flashpoint in the Trump administration’s trade war with China
item.description: Toy makers are raising prices and are cautious about producing more amid uncertainty over whether U.S. tariffs on China imports will jump again.
item.dc:creator: An Rong Xu

item.title: Heard on the Street: Are steel tariffs as bulletproof as investors seem to believe?
item.description: Increase is piggybacking on seven-year-old findings. Are they too stale?
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weil

item.title: U.S. job growth slowed slightly last month, a sign employers grew more cautious about hiring
item.description: The U.S. added 139,000 jobs in May, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.2%.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: European Industry Contracts as Tariffs Pull Exports Lower
item.description: Industrial production in France and Germany declined in the first month of Trump’s global tariff blitz, with goods exports to the U.S. from the latter also falling sharply.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Despite High Inflation
item.description: The Bank of Russia lowered its key interest rate for the first time since late 2022, even with inflation remaining well above its target.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: India Central Bank Delivers Larger-Than-Expected Rate Cut to Support Growth
item.description: India’s central bank surprised markets with a jumbo rate cut, seizing on cooling inflation to frontload monetary easing and bolster economic growth amid heightened global uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: ECB Has Won Battle Against Inflation in the Eurozone, Villeroy Says
item.description: Europe has succeeded in bringing inflation under control after a surge driven by the end of the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the head of France’s central bank said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China Central Bank Pumps Liquidity Into Markets Amid Cash-Crunch Concerns
item.description: The move is likely aimed at cushioning against an emerging cash crunch as trade tensions simmer.

item.title: RBA Upbeat on China’s Willingness to Do What It Takes on Growth
item.description: High-profile visits by senior Australian central bank officials have returned a verdict of confidence that China remains well-placed to ride out the upheavals emerging from U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate
item.description: Analysts polled by The Wall Street Journal are expecting the Labor Department’s report to show that the U.S. added a net 125,000 jobs in May.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Labor-Market Outlook Cautious Ahead of May Jobs Report
item.description: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Live Q&A: Deficit, Debt and Markets—We Answer Your Biggest Questions
item.description: WSJ subscribers can submit their questions to our economics reporters in the comments space. Sort by “Most Liked” to see their responses.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Canada Goods-Trade Deficit Widens to Record C$7.14 Billion in April
item.description: It was a third straight trade deficit for Canada, and a much bigger shortfall than the C$1.5 billion economists expected.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: President Trump’s tariffs threaten to crimp U.S. economic growth this year while boosting inflation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a new forecast
item.description: The research group expects the Fed to remain on hold this year, as the economy is hamstrung by uncertainty over whipsawing U.S. trade policy, according to the OECD.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Falls Below Target
item.description: Consumer prices were 1.9% higher on year in May, down from 2.2% in April, as the ECB moves closer to securing victory over inflation.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: ECB Set to Cut Rates Again and Keep Options Open
item.description: Investors expect a rate cut Thursday to be among the last in this sequence unless the eurozone economy is threatened by recession.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. How it does so will have a big impact on home buyers and homeowners.
item.description: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in two government-controlled companies that are crucial for getting a mortgage. But it first needs to figure out what it wants the mortgage market to look like.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Governments will have to “work hard” to fix economic imbalances and roll back the spread of subsidies that have fueled challenges to the free-trade system, Bank of England Gov. Andrew Bailey said.
item.description: The head of the Bank of England says strains in the global trading system that have most recently been manifested in higher U.S. tariffs make life difficult for central bankers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Pending Home Sales Slump as Mortgage Prices Weigh
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. fell sharply in April, as high mortgage prices continue to hamper the market, according to a monthly index.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Rose Last Week
item.description: In the week through May 24, 240,000 people newly filed for unemployment benefits, compared with 226,000 the week prior and economists’ expectations of 230,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: First-Time Home Buyers Downsize Amid Tight Supply, High Interest Rates
item.description: Home buyers are more willing to sacrifice size if it means finding a listing that works within their budget.
item.dc:creator: Denny Jacob

item.title: Sales of existing homes declined in April, after mounting economic uncertainty and steep housing costs pushed buyers away for the second consecutive month
item.description: The slowest sales pace for any April in 16 years indicates the spring selling season is shaping up as a bust.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled
item.description: The president has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: U.S. Housing Starts Ticked Up in April
item.description: The gauge of new residential construction rose 1.6% last month to 1.36 million, according to the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.K. Consumers’ Mood Darkens Under Tariff Clouds
item.description: Consumers in the U.K. are growing more pessimistic as they fear the weight of trade tariffs and renewed high inflation, according to research group GfK.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby
